lens.book_chapters: Introduction + Chapters 1-3: Choice Architecture, Defaults, and Framing

disappointment_summary: Roomster is optimized for getting users into motion quickly, but it leaves the highest-risk decisions under-structured: users are pushed into search and chat with strong speed framing, weak trust defaults, and little guidance for comparison, commitment, or post-outcome learning. Nothing is technically broken, yet repeated small design choices let heuristics, urgency, and social proof substitute for calibrated judgment.

disappointments.title: Speed-First Discovery Frame Crowds Out Risk Framing
disappointments.what_happens_now: First-touch messaging emphasizes fast matching and broad inventory, so users enter with a 'find something now' mindset before they see any structured guidance on scam patterns, verification depth, or realistic match odds.
disappointments.why_its_not_a_bug: The acquisition flow performs its job by driving clicks and signups, so there is no obvious functional failure to report.
disappointments.why_it_matters_psychologically: Introduction framing effects mean early salience sets the reference point for later decisions; once speed is mentally anchored, users underweight low-frequency but high-cost risks.

evidence.observation: Order and salience predictably steer choices even when options stay open.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Top-of-funnel framing acts as a nudge that preloads users toward speed over caution.

evidence.observation: Roomster acquisition touchpoints foreground fast room/roommate discovery and inventory scale.
evidence.framework_interpretation: The platform's first impression sets a conversion anchor rather than a trust anchor.

disappointments.the_coffee_test: This is mediocre coffee because users accept 'that is just how roommate apps are'; a trust-first discovery default would feel surprisingly premium.

disappointments.title: Ranking Without Probability Cues
disappointments.what_happens_now: Users scroll ranked cards with headline rent and limited context, then manually open profiles to infer response likelihood, compatibility odds, and legitimacy from sparse clues.
disappointments.why_its_not_a_bug: Search returns results and filters function, so the system appears to work as expected.
disappointments.why_it_matters_psychologically: Chapter 1 shows anchoring and availability biases dominate when probabilities are missing; users mistake what is most visible for what is most likely to succeed safely.

evidence.observation: People rely on salient anchors and vivid examples when estimating value and risk.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Top-ranked cards become de facto recommendations in the absence of calibrated signals.

evidence.observation: Roomster search is optimized for browsing and lead generation, not explicit fit/trust probability defaults.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Users must do extra cognitive work the interface could scaffold.

disappointments.the_coffee_test: This is mediocre coffee because everyone accepts tab-hopping comparison as normal, but guided probability cues would meaningfully delight.

disappointments.title: Polished Profiles Masquerade as Safety Signals
disappointments.what_happens_now: During profile evaluation, users infer trust from photo quality, writing tone, and lifestyle similarity, while hard disconfirming checks are not surfaced as a default sequence before contacting.
disappointments.why_its_not_a_bug: Profiles display correctly and users can message, so the experience passes as functional.
disappointments.why_it_matters_psychologically: Chapter 1 representativeness bias causes people to confuse 'looks legitimate' with 'is low risk'; without structured checks, stereotype-based inference fills the gap.

evidence.observation: Similarity cues and inertia can lock people into poor judgments.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Once a profile 'feels right,' users underinvest in verification.

evidence.observation: Evaluation relies on variable profile depth and user-led diligence rather than structured trust prompts.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Critical safety work is offloaded to user intuition.

disappointments.the_coffee_test: This is mediocre coffee because people tolerate vibe-based screening; a default disconfirming checklist would feel unexpectedly protective.

disappointments.title: No Structured Commitment Step Before Going Off-Platform
disappointments.what_happens_now: After initial match interest, users move into free-form negotiation without native proposal milestones, standardized terms, or reversible commitment checkpoints.
disappointments.why_its_not_a_bug: The product intentionally stops at matching and messaging, so absence of a contract flow is seen as scope rather than defect.
disappointments.why_it_matters_psychologically: The Introduction notes active choosing is itself architecture; forcing high-stakes active choosing in complex contexts increases omission errors and susceptibility to manipulative framing.

evidence.source: nudge-choice-architecture.txt - Introduction (active choosing, inevitability of architecture)
evidence.observation: People do not always want forced active choice when options are numerous and consequences unclear.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Unguided negotiation amplifies errors at the exact point stakes escalate.

evidence.observation: Roomster funnels users to direct contact instead of in-product offer/acceptance workflow.
evidence.framework_interpretation: The riskiest phase lacks safety defaults and quality control.

disappointments.the_coffee_test: This is mediocre coffee because users expect to handle terms themselves; a guided commitment path would feel notably better than category norms.

disappointments.title: Chat Momentum Becomes a False Legitimacy Signal
disappointments.what_happens_now: Messaging is a generic back-and-forth where fast replies and conversational warmth are implicitly treated as quality signals, with no built-in prompts for verification artifacts or expectation alignment.
disappointments.why_its_not_a_bug: Messages send and users connect, so the core feature works and conversion remains high.
disappointments.why_it_matters_psychologically: Chapter 2 present bias and Chapter 3 herd effects make immediate social feedback feel safer than it is; users over-trust responsiveness over evidence.

evidence.observation: People overweight immediate rewards under self-control pressure.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Quick social reinforcement drives premature commitment behavior.

evidence.observation: In uncertainty, social cues heavily influence choices.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Conversation momentum functions as weak social proof in place of hard trust signals.

disappointments.the_coffee_test: This is mediocre coffee because plain chat is expected, but safety-structured conversation defaults would feel unusually thoughtful.

disappointments.title: Silence After Match Agreement
disappointments.what_happens_now: Once roommates decide to proceed, coordination for chores, boundaries, utilities, and conflict handling happens outside the platform with no periodic check-in or norm-setting defaults.
disappointments.why_its_not_a_bug: Roomster is positioned as a matching product, so post-match support is not an explicit promise users expect to be fulfilled.
disappointments.why_it_matters_psychologically: The Introduction's 'everything matters' principle implies missing small structures creates preventable friction; without defaults, status quo drift lets unresolved issues compound.

evidence.observation: Small contextual design decisions can produce large behavioral effects.
evidence.framework_interpretation: No post-match scaffolding means predictable coordination failures are left unmanaged.

evidence.observation: The platform provides minimal native tenancy lifecycle support after matching.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Behavioral architecture stops before the outcome is lived.

disappointments.the_coffee_test: This is mediocre coffee because users do not expect help after matching, so even lightweight stay guidance would feel surprisingly valuable.

disappointments.title: No Structured Debrief to Recalibrate Future Choices
disappointments.what_happens_now: After outcomes are known, users are not guided through a concise reflection on what signals were reliable, what red flags were missed, and what to change next search cycle.
disappointments.why_its_not_a_bug: Users can leave and return later without obstruction, so there is no visible defect in core flow completion.
disappointments.why_it_matters_psychologically: Chapter 1 availability bias causes recent vivid incidents to dominate memory; without structured recall, learning is noisy and overreactive.

evidence.observation: People overweight memorable events and underweight base rates in later judgments.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Absent debrief defaults, users carry forward distorted lessons.

evidence.observation: Roommate platforms generally have thin closure and review rituals compared with travel marketplaces.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Weak feedback architecture reduces collective and individual calibration.

disappointments.the_coffee_test: This is mediocre coffee because nobody expects a learning loop, so a short post-stay recalibration would feel unexpectedly smart.

disappointments.title: Renewal Inertia Over Decision-Quality Retention
disappointments.what_happens_now: Ongoing engagement depends on recurring search need and subscription continuity, while retention messaging focuses on access and volume rather than whether users are making safer, higher-quality choices over time.
disappointments.why_its_not_a_bug: Renewals and reactivations happen, so business metrics may look acceptable despite shallow user learning.
disappointments.why_it_matters_psychologically: Chapter 1 status quo bias means users stick with defaults; if defaults optimize continuation instead of better judgment, long-run trust deteriorates even when short-run activity persists.

evidence.source: nudge-choice-architecture.txt - Chapter 1 (status quo bias, default effects)
evidence.observation: People disproportionately remain with current settings and default paths.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Retention can be sustained by inertia even when perceived decision quality is not improving.

evidence.observation: Users often appreciate reach but question trust and pricing fairness over longer use horizons.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Conversion-centered nudges can produce cumulative reactance and loyalty decay.

disappointments.the_coffee_test: This is mediocre coffee because recurring access is treated as enough; retention built on better decisions would pleasantly break expectations.

disappointment_clusters.pattern: Roomster creates strong behavioral momentum but weak explicit trust scaffolding, so users rely on vibe, speed, and social cues instead of evidence.
disappointment_clusters.signature_potential: A trust-first architecture with disconfirming defaults could become a category-defining differentiator for Split Lease.

disappointment_clusters.pattern: Search and commitment moments require user-built decision systems rather than platform-provided choice architecture.
disappointment_clusters.signature_potential: Probability-aware comparison and staged commitment workflows could convert invisible labor into visible product value.

disappointment_clusters.cluster_name: No Behavioral Support After Initial Match
disappointment_clusters.pattern: Product investment drops after match initiation, so users lose support for coordination, reflection, and improved future decisions.
disappointment_clusters.signature_potential: A full lifecycle guidance layer could compound trust and decision quality, turning retention into an outcome of better choices, not inertia.
